chapters.name: Macedonia and the Boy Prince (356-340 BCE)
topics: Who was Alexander's father Philip II of Macedon — a brilliant military reformer who transformed a backwater kingdom into the dominant power in Greece — and how did Philip's ambition, tactical genius, and violent court shape his son?

What was Alexander's education under Aristotle (343-340 BCE) — three years of private tutoring from history's greatest philosopher — and how did lessons in science, medicine, philosophy, and Homer's Iliad shape a future conqueror?

How did the toxic dynamics of Alexander's family — his father Philip's polygamy, his mother Olympias's fierce ambition and claims of divine parentage, and the constant threat of rival heirs — create a young man driven by insecurity as much as ambition?

What was Macedonia like in the 4th century BCE — a Greek-speaking kingdom considered semi-barbarous by Athens and Sparta — and how did Philip II's military innovations (the sarissa pike, the Macedonian phalanx, combined arms tactics) make it the most formidable military power in the ancient world?

How did Alexander first prove himself militarily — commanding the left wing at the Battle of Chaeronea (338 BCE) at age 18, where his cavalry charge destroyed the Sacred Band of Thebes — and what did this victory reveal about his abilities?

chapters.name: The Conquest of Persia (334-330 BCE)
topics: How did Alexander cross the Hellespont in 334 BCE with roughly 47,000 soldiers to invade the Persian Empire — which controlled territory from Egypt to India with a population of perhaps 50 million — and why did this seemingly suicidal gamble succeed?

What happened at the Battle of Issus (333 BCE) — where Alexander defeated Darius III despite being outnumbered, captured the Persian king's family, and refused Darius's offer of half his empire — revealing both military genius and personal recklessness?

How did Alexander's siege of Tyre (332 BCE) — building a half-mile causeway to reach an island fortress over seven months — demonstrate the relentless determination that made him unstoppable and the brutality that followed resistance?

What was the Battle of Gaugamela (331 BCE) — Alexander's decisive victory over Darius III's army of perhaps 100,000 on a battlefield the Persian king had chosen and prepared — and how did Alexander's tactical innovation (the oblique advance, the decisive cavalry wedge) destroy the largest empire in the world?

How did Alexander treat conquered peoples — preserving local governance, respecting religious customs, and incorporating Persian nobles into his administration — and was this genuine cultural openness or shrewd imperial management?

chapters.name: Egypt, Babylon, and the God-King
topics: Why did Alexander visit the Oracle of Amun at Siwa (331 BCE) — crossing 300 miles of desert to a remote Egyptian oasis — and what did the oracle allegedly tell him that reinforced his belief in his own divinity?

How did Alexander found Alexandria in Egypt (331 BCE) — the most famous of the 20+ cities he founded — and why did it become the intellectual capital of the ancient world, home to the Great Library and a beacon of Hellenistic culture for centuries?

What did Alexander's entry into Babylon reveal about his approach to empire — accepting the submission of local priests, restoring the temple of Marduk that the Persians had damaged, and positioning himself as liberator rather than conqueror?

How did Alexander's claim to divine status evolve — from the Siwa oracle to demanding proskynesis (ritual prostration) from his followers — and why did this alienate his Macedonian officers who saw it as oriental despotism?

What happened when Alexander found and buried Darius III (330 BCE) — murdered by his own satrap Bessus — and how did Alexander's pursuit and execution of Bessus demonstrate his claim to be the legitimate successor of the Persian kings, not merely their destroyer?

chapters.name: Into Central Asia and India (330-326 BCE)
topics: How did the guerrilla wars in Bactria and Sogdiana (330-327 BCE) — modern Afghanistan and Central Asia — prove far more difficult than the pitched battles against Persia, foreshadowing every subsequent empire's failure to control this region?

What happened at the Battle of the Hydaspes (326 BCE) — Alexander's last great battle, fought against King Porus and his war elephants in monsoon rains — and why did Alexander honor his defeated enemy rather than humiliate him?

Why did Alexander's army mutiny at the Hyphasis River (326 BCE) — refusing to march further east after eight years of continuous campaigning — and how did this moment reveal the limits of even the most charismatic leadership?

What was the catastrophic march through the Gedrosian Desert (325 BCE) — where Alexander lost perhaps a quarter of his army to heat, thirst, and starvation — and was this a navigational miscalculation or deliberate punishment of his troops for the mutiny?
How far did Alexander actually get — from Greece to the Punjab, roughly 11,000 miles of marching — and what would have happened had his army not stopped him at the Hyphasis?

chapters.name: The Killing of Friends
topics: How did Alexander murder his friend Cleitus the Black (328 BCE) — running him through with a spear during a drunken argument — and what does this killing reveal about Alexander's increasing volatility, alcoholism, and inability to tolerate dissent?

What was the conspiracy of Philotas and the execution of Parmenion (330 BCE) — Alexander's most experienced general, murdered on his son's unproven guilt — and how did the elimination of potential rivals become a pattern?

Why did Alexander execute his court historian Callisthenes (327 BCE) — Aristotle's own nephew — for refusing to perform proskynesis, and what did this reveal about the growing distance between Alexander and the Macedonian values he was raised with?

How did the Pages' Conspiracy (327 BCE) — a plot by royal pages to assassinate Alexander in his sleep — reflect the growing discontent among young Macedonian nobles who felt Alexander had become more Persian despot than Greek king?

What was the relationship between Alexander and Hephaestion — his closest companion from childhood, possibly his lover, and the man whose death in 324 BCE sent Alexander into a grief so extreme he ordered the execution of the doctor and demanded divine honors for the dead man?

chapters.name: Death and the Wars of Succession
topics: How did Alexander die in Babylon on June 10 or 11, 323 BCE, at age 32 — after a prolonged drinking bout and 10 days of fever — and why do theories range from typhoid to poisoning to the cumulative effect of multiple battle wounds and alcoholism?
What were Alexander's plans had he lived — reportedly preparing to invade Arabia, then possibly Carthage and the western Mediterranean — and how might the ancient world have developed differently?

How did Alexander's generals carve up his empire in the Wars of the Diadochi (322-281 BCE) — Ptolemy taking Egypt, Seleucus taking Persia and Mesopotamia, Antigonus fighting for everything — creating the Hellenistic kingdoms that would dominate the Mediterranean until Rome?

What happened to Alexander's family — his wife Roxane and son Alexander IV both murdered by 310 BCE, his mother Olympias killed, his half-brother executed — in the brutal power struggles that consumed everyone connected to him?
Why did Alexander's empire fragment immediately upon his death — lasting only 13 years as a unified state — and what does this reveal about empires built entirely around a single personality?

chapters.name: Military Genius: How Alexander Won
topics: What made Alexander one of history's greatest military commanders — undefeated in battle across 15 years, adapting tactics to every terrain and enemy — and how did he combine the Macedonian phalanx, companion cavalry, and shock tactics into an unbeatable system?

How did Alexander's personal leadership style — always leading from the front, suffering multiple serious wounds, sharing the hardships of his men — inspire extraordinary loyalty while putting the entire enterprise at constant risk?

What role did logistics play in Alexander's campaigns — feeding and moving 47,000+ soldiers across 11,000 miles through deserts, mountains, and hostile territory — and how did his logistical planning match his tactical brilliance?

How did Alexander adapt to enemies who fought differently than the Persians — guerrilla warfare in Afghanistan, war elephants in India, naval sieges at Tyre — demonstrating a flexibility that many great generals lack?

What was Alexander's approach to siege warfare — from the engineering marvel of the Tyre causeway to the assault on the Sogdian Rock (reportedly unconquerable, taken in days) — and how did he solve problems that conventional armies couldn't?

chapters.name: The Hellenistic World Alexander Created
topics: What was Hellenization — the spread of Greek language, culture, philosophy, and urban planning across Alexander's conquered territories — and how did it create a shared cultural framework from Egypt to Afghanistan that lasted centuries?

How did the Library of Alexandria — founded by Ptolemy I, one of Alexander's generals — become the greatest repository of knowledge in the ancient world, and what was lost when it was eventually destroyed?

What was the Hellenistic fusion of Greek and Eastern cultures — Greek-Buddhist art in Gandhara, Egyptian-Greek religion, Persian-Greek administrative systems — and was this genuine cultural exchange or Greek cultural imperialism?

How did Alexander's conquests spread Greek language so effectively that koine Greek became the lingua franca of the eastern Mediterranean for centuries — the language in which the New Testament would be written and the language of science and philosophy?

What economic changes did Alexander's empire create — the release of Persian treasury gold flooding Mediterranean markets, new trade routes connecting India to Greece, the standardization of coinage — and how did these reshape the ancient economy?

chapters.name: Alexander in History and Legend
topics: How did the Alexander Romance — a fictionalized biography written in the centuries after his death, translated into 80 languages — transform a historical figure into a mythic hero known from Iceland to Indonesia?

Why has Alexander been claimed by so many national traditions — as a Greek hero, a Macedonian founder, an Egyptian pharaoh, a Persian king, an Islamic prophet (Dhul-Qarnayn), and a symbol of European superiority — and what does this reveal about how history serves identity?

How have modern historians reassessed Alexander — from the 19th-century romanticization of a civilizing hero to 20th-century critiques of a megalomaniac drunk who left destruction in his wake — and which assessment is closer to the evidence?

Why does the modern dispute between Greece and North Macedonia over Alexander's legacy — including a 30-year name dispute resolved only in 2019 — demonstrate that ancient history remains politically explosive?

What would Alexander think of the world he created — the Hellenistic kingdoms, the spread of Greek culture, the eventual absorption of his legacy by Rome — and does his vision of a multicultural empire deserve the admiration it has received?
